name: Confederation of Sahel States
ariaLabel: Flags of Burkina Faso, Mali, and Niger
currentCrisisSummary:
The Central Sahel (Burkina Faso, Mali, Niger) suffers a severe crisis born from converging **structural violence**: weak governance inherited from **colonialism** and gutted by **neoliberalism**, jihadist insurgencies fuelled by **state collapse** and **failed Western interventions**, recurrent **coups** reflecting popular rejection of **neo-colonial** security models, and accelerating **climate shocks**.

Recent military takeovers signal a shift, creating a new **geopolitical** frontline involving **Russian mercenaries** (Wagner/Africa Corps). Violence, driven by armed groups and **predatory control of resources**, inflicts mass displacement and starvation. The human cost is amplified by long-term **extractive relations** and **external interference**. Ending the suffering requires Sahelian-led political solutions and dismantling **extractive** and **militarised responses** imposed from outside.

colonialRoot.legacy:
**French colonial rule** reorganised borders and economies favouring **extraction**. At independence, formal sovereignty didn't erase these structures: monetary arrangements (**CFA franc**), security pacts, and '**FranÃ§afrique**' networks allowed continued French influence.

These arrangements left fragile states, **export-oriented economies**, and weak governance, conditions contributing to later instability.

historicalContext.title: Neoliberalism and the Hollowed-Out State
historicalContext.description: During debt crises (1980s-90s), Sahelian states adopted **IMF/World Bank-led Structural Adjustment Programmes (SAPs)**. These **neoliberal policies** mandated severe **austerity**, dismantling public services. This '**hollowing out**' of the state created a governance vacuum, destroyed livelihoods, and eroded trust, a root cause of current insurgencies.

historicalContext.title: The War on Terror and Failed Interventions
historicalContext.description: Post-2001, the Sahel became a frontier in the global '**War on Terror**', prioritising militarised responses. The 2011 **NATO-led intervention in Libya** dismantled a state, creating a **power vacuum** fuelling the 2012 Mali insurgency. Subsequent **French interventions** (Operation Barkhane) continued this security-first approach, creating **dependency** and backlash leading to **anti-French coups**.

historicalContext.title: Resource Extraction and Neo-Colonialism
historicalContext.description: Poverty contrasts with mineral wealth coveted by **foreign powers**. Niger's strategic **uranium** supply for France exemplifies **neo-colonial** relations: French state corporations extract profits while Niger remains impoverished. This **resource plunder** drives **anti-French sentiment**.

historicalContext.title: Russia's Entry: Mercenaries for Minerals
historicalContext.description: Exploiting the backlash against France, **Russia** has expanded its influence, primarily through **private military contractors** (Wagner Group/Africa Corps). Military juntas in Mali, Burkina Faso, and Niger increasingly rely on these **mercenaries** for regime security, often granting them access to **mining concessions** (gold, etc.). This replicates a **neo-colonial resource-for-security** model, fuelling abuses with **impunity**.

historicalContext.title: ECOWAS Sanctions and Regional Fractures
historicalContext.description: Following the coups (esp. Niger 2023), the **Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS)** imposed **punitive sanctions**, including border closures and asset freezes. Widely seen as illegitimate and externally pressured (by France/West), these sanctions caused **severe humanitarian suffering** (blocking food/medicine), alienated populations, and accelerated the juntas' pivot towards **Russia** and the formation of the **Confederation of Sahel States**.

historicalContext.title: Climate Change and Regional Instability
historicalContext.description: The Sahel is on the frontline of the **climate emergency** despite minimal emissions. Desertification undermines livelihoods, worsening resource competition. This is **climatic injustice** or '**climate colonialism**', where costs of Northern industrialisation are borne by Sahelian communities.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Tens of thousands killed by violence from insurgencies, **state repression**, **mercenary abuses**, and conflict exacerbated by **external interference**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Est. 18 million require aid due to breakdown caused by **conflict**, **neoliberal policies**, **punitive sanctions**, and **climate shocks**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Millions face acute hunger, driven by **conflict**, **climate change**, **ECOWAS sanctions**, and failed development models.

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 3.3 million internally displaced by **jihadist attacks**, military operations, and resource conflicts linked to **climate change**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugees
humanitarianImpact.description: Nearly 1 million forced abroad by violence and **state collapse**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Hundreds of health centres closed due to attacks, insecurity, and underfunding rooted in **austerity** and exacerbated by **sanctions**.

timeline.event: **French Conquest**: France consolidates control across West Africa, imposing borders and administrative systems that reconfigured local polities.
**Nominal Independence**: Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger gain independence but remain embedded in post-colonial monetary and security arrangements linked to France.
**NATO Intervention in Libya**: The collapse of Libya's state after 2011 disperses weapons and fighters across the Sahel, amplifying regional insecurity.
**Northern Mali Insurgency**: A Tuareg rebellion in northern Mali is overtaken by jihadist groups, triggering a major regional crisis.
**Operation Barkhane & French Failure**: France deploys Operation Barkhane across the Sahel; despite sustained military effort, jihadist violence spreads and French presence fuels popular resentment.
**Wave of Coups**: Military juntas seize power in Mali, Burkina Faso and Niger, expelling French forces and seeking new security partners, notably **Russian mercenaries** (Wagner/Africa Corps).
**Niger Coup & ECOWAS Sanctions**: Following the coup in Niger, ECOWAS imposes harsh sanctions, causing humanitarian suffering and pushing the juntas closer together.
**Confederation of Sahel States**: Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso form a confederation, withdraw from ECOWAS, and deepen ties with **Russia**, shifting the region's geopolitical alignments.
**Deepening Crisis**: Violence intensifies in many areas as jihadist groups expand, state forces and **Russian mercenaries** commit abuses, producing rising displacement and humanitarian need.

donate.description: An African-led organisation partnering with rural communities on food security and climate-resilient livelihoods.

advocacy.title: Shift from Military to Political Solutions
advocacy.description: Push for a shift away from militarised counter-terrorism strategies towards Sahelian-led political, social and development solutions that address root causes.

advocacy.title: Oppose All Foreign Interference
advocacy.description: Oppose all forms of external interference, whether **French neo-colonialism**, **Russian mercenary deployment**, or **punitive sanctions regimes**, that undermine sovereignty and harm civilians.

advocacy.title: Demand Corporate Accountability
advocacy.description: Demand transparency and enforceable corporate due diligence on mineral (esp. **uranium, gold**) and agricultural supply chains that link Northern consumption to local dispossession.

advocacy.title: Advocate for Climate Reparations
advocacy.description: Advocate for climate reparations and increased, flexible climate finance for locally led adaptation and resilience-building projects.
